When you look at a chart imagine how various timeframe participants would feel and might be motivated if they are long, short or in cash

@invester1245 @bowtiedavax Definitely not - much more to trading than just levels. An understanding of context needed, a well developed trade management methodology for post-entry, mastery of a few entry techniques. No shortcuts to putting in the work and screen time

@Matt_Stoughton For sure - Twitter tends to give the false impression good traders are gurus who know what every next move is. In the real world, most elite traders and funds are pushing win rates in the 45-65% zone, and master risk managers
@bowtiedavax Absolutely - one of the best traders I've known personally was winning around 40-45% of trades utilizing a mean reversion strategy, but was able to generate outsized R/R on the 40%
@ashikshare My size varies trade to trade, but I shoot for a 1:1 R/R minimum for my 1st profit take, then let any runners boost it from there

Key to remember one can win just 55% of trades with a 1 to 2 risk/reward ratio and be very nicely profitable. Not about winning every trade or catching all of every move; a few good R/R pieces a week and disciplined loss control, over a big sample, is where real growth is found

@AlphaSigma888 I never draw wedges and only draw parallel lines. Wedges are far too subjective, and they can also endlessly be adjusted (which is why they notoriously keep new traders on the wrong side of trends). If it breaks upward, one can simply adjust it slightly to keep the wedge alive
@JamesCh55232476 Seasonally the strength in December is in the back half of the month. The "Santa rally" phenomenon refers typically to the week before and after Christmas

@kyleprohaska I try not to engage too much in the crystal ball game (nobody can forecast this far out - I care only about making money and to do that means I need to worry about the next actionable trades). If I had to guess I do think we get a messy Dec rally followed by decent Jan weakness

@BillyBob7320988 That would be the next major magnet up. It needs to get through the down-trend channel first though, and that will take a new base to build first. If it clears with momentum though (perhaps after CPI/FOMC) that line would be next up

@AlphaSigma888 It's not a bear pattern - its simply a rising channel (and as I've written in my newsletter, the #1 reason I've been bullish since October 13th). It becomes bearish only if it fails. It is a channel because support and resistance are perfectly parallel; the criteria for a channel

@mundo2point0 @bbakowski11 @patrman On a well tested level though depending on the action around it I can often give it much less space, like a couple points, or will even front-run the breakdown. All depends on the surrounding price action.

@mundo2point0 @bbakowski11 @patrman Yes - its all about the price action and context and there is no single rule that I've found that can define a level break with much more than 50% accuracy. As a very general rule I use 8-10 points, ideally on a level with 2-3 tests. Level breaks are a skill that take screentime

@patrman A failed breakdown is a very specific pattern as shown in my method section point 8. It nearly always looks like that and is more rare. A level recapture is just what it says - any prior support that was lost reclaiming (or resistance that was broken up failing back down)

Gotta do what works for you, not here to convince anyone otherwise.

Seasonal tendencies are last, I know when good times typically are (December always one of my best months)  and slower trade in summer etc

An open mind will always serve better than a dogmatic fundamental vs technical approach

I am a trader so, I am price based.  I use price action to find ideas, determine entry, risk and exit

I am aware of fundamentals because I want to be aware of what motivates others to have confidence to hold or add to a stock

a PE Ratio is similar to a 50 DMA or "Santa Claus Rally"

Fundamental valuations R Y 2 study the business

Technical studies R a price #levelofinterest for stock analysis

Seasonal studies are a time based

by themselves they are reasons to study closer, not take action blindly

@Sglatz1 For sure - 99% of newer traders will blow out trading with size. If you don't have a demonstrated edge trading larger size just means blow out comes faster. Even with a verified edge though, I'm still a big fan of small size, much easier to stay disciplined!

When a stock (or market) reaches an important technical level on the way down
 -shorts stop adding
- some shorts start to cover
- longs slow down sales
- sidelined cash starts to nibble

it is a slow transition of supply driven market to demand driven, it is how support forms

@WaterMartyr yw Michael

@WaterMartyr 390 Minutes per day
5 days x 390 minutes = 1950 min for 5 days

divide your timeframe into 1950 for the corresponding value of the 5 DMA

1950/65 min TF = 30
so the 30 period MA on a 65 min TF = 5 days

1950/195 (2 candles/ day) = 10
10period MA on 195 min TF = 5DMA

etc

basic English I see traders constantly get wrong

Lose is a verb that means ‚Äúto fail to win, to misplace.‚Äù Loose is an adjective that means ‚Äúnot tight.‚Äù

You lose more money with a loose stop.
@JagdipBal @cathiesark ONLY needs 200% rally for that to happen! :)

A dip is NOT a stock in a downtrend.  If the stock is below declining key moving averages such as 20, 50, 100, 150, 200 it is a stock in a downtrend.  Weakness in these stocks are lower lows.  Do NOT buy these stocks unless you like to lose money

2/2

As much as I dislike many of the market labels & definitions, it seems like we need to define a "dip."

A "dip" is a short term pullback (does not make a lower low) of a stock in an UPtrend.  A dip will typically decline no more than 5-7% in a few days & then quickly recover

-YTD VWAP

@iliResearch On the daily chart since Feb 2nd, we are in a range wide range box between 4580 and 4440. There is no clear trend in this phase. From a day trading perspective, we are certainly squeezing

@iliResearch If the average return of a fund over 20 years is 15%, it does not mean it will perform at exactly 15% year, there will be a range clustered around that center point and its the same with seasonals. Right now, the general seasonal idea is low late Jan, high mid Feb

@iliResearch Yes it is on the daily chart since Feb 2nd or so. But seasonality is not this precise regardless..it is a crude average over 20 years so it needs to be treated as such. The important thing is the timing of the turn points +/- regular variance
@jwbpark Same levels, 4530, 4517ish. Could just base out here also

@iliResearch Not at all - important to remember seasonality is an average, not a precise day to day timer. Its most useful when looking at the turn points (very late Jan low is set, mid Feb in around a week high is set) +/- several days to account for the averaging effect. Tracking perfect

@slanggungan Different dataset. That looks at the 5 day average return from the date shown over last 50 years. The one I posted uses the avg YTD for a given date over a 20 year sample. Difference between the 2 likely just reflects that Jan isn't a month with super strong seasonal tendencies

@DawareMo Its not supposed to be a precise map of price (otherwise SPX would just do the same thing every year). It's a rough long term average. The main thing is the turn points (for example, high set early month, low set late month).

@GuptaBioDD @rinoathf This is very important. This chart is just an average its not supposed to be a precise map of what price does or will do (otherwise ES would just do the same thing every year). It's mainly just useful for locating rough inflection points, a slightly above random % of the time
